text:
These were very nice. I was expecting outstanding flavour for five stars though and this just didn't make it. Next time I would add sweet chilli sauce, more tomato and garlic. Fresh basil is a must! UPDATE: I have now modified this recipe to suit our family's taste and I have to say that it is worthy of 5* now. Instead of tomato sauce, I used a whole can of diced tomatoes, doubled the garlic, more basil, 1/4 cup sweet chilli sauce, 1 tblsn of red wine vinegar, 1/4 cup oil and pulsed the lot in my food processor. Verrryyy nice.

text:
For a small Oscar Party I made an arrangement of skewer recipes.  My friend Kristi ABSOLUTELY loved this one.  But a word to the wise, if you for some reason not to grill the shrimp and instead make it on the stove, BIG mistake.  I became lazy and mad waiting for my boyfriend and decided to use the stove and a skillet.  It had to be scrapped, the grill allows some of the seasonings to air out especially the garlic and adds a great taste that can not be replicated on the stove.

text:
This recipe is AWESOME!!!  Made these for a 4th of July party and they literally flew off the table.  After reading other reviews, I used the largest shrimp I could find, replaced the tomato sauce with chili sauce, upped the cayenne pepper, marinated them for two hours and then grilled.  People were raving about them and calling to each other to come try them.  Definitely a success.  Thanks so much for this recipe!!!

text:
I marinated 1 lb. of shrimp (the frozen, peeled and deveined kind) in a full batch of the marinade (enough for 2 people).  I used dried basil, white wine vinegar, and extra garlic.  I then made a seperate double batch of the marinade with a huge piece of elephant garlic which I then emulsified in the blender and then heated on the stove. I cooked the shrimp in a skillet over medium-high heat until pink and served it over angel-hair pasta with the extra sauce and some parmesan cheese.  My husband raved over it and even has me passing out the recipe to his co-workers!!!  Definitely a keeper!

text:
Just perfect and delicious as written, though I didn't bother with skewers since I only made enough shrimp for hubby and myself.  No need to change a thing, unless you feel some compelling desire to do so. Just enough flavor and seasoning--enough to be noticeable, but in a way that enhances the shrimp rather than overpowering its own wonderful and delicate flavor. This is an example of how using a few simple but flavorful and fresh ingredients is usually best.

text:
OMG, this is hands-down the best shrimp i have ever tasted in my whole entire life.  this marinade is soooooo good..i think it's the combination of all the ingredients that makes this so tasty.  i brushed the left-over marinade over the shrimp while it was on the grill.  this recipe is highly recommended!!!!!  TIP: even if you don't have time to let the shrimp marinate for one hour, just throw everything together and brush the rest of the marinade on the shrimp while its grilling...it still tastes amazing!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was very good!  The first time we made it we used small pre-cooked shrimp and grilled it on the Foreman Grill (without skewers) and it came out great.  The second time, we doubled the marinade and then cooked the shrimp and marinade in a skillet and poured it over rice.  The heat made the sauce pretty thin so now I reserve 1/2 cup marinade and add one tablespoon cornstarch to it, then combine it all in the skillet.  *TIP: One thing I do different is I only use a quarter or a third of the olive oil called for.  It doesn't really add anything and it just kinda separates into this oily layer floating on top, not really blending with the tomato sauce.  Now I usually quadruple the marinade (with the exception of the olive oil) when using the marinade as a sauce.  We've also made this with small pieces of chicken and it is very good!  Thanks for this recipe!

text:
I'll admit, I was skeptical at first....the ingredients seemed a bit odd together.  And then I ate it.  WOW!  This is fantastic, the BEST.  I made it exactly as the recipe states, and it has gained the highest rating in my cookbook, "The Standard", which means look no more for a better recipe!  It's the closest I've come to the best shrimp I've ever had in my life, which was at a Cozumel beach bar/grill and the owner was NOT coming out with the recipe.  This makes me fantasize a little less about HIS shrimp.  :)
ADDENDUM 2/16/03----------Still LOVE this recipe, and I'm delighted to find that it turned out great after just two minutes in my George Foreman grill.  Don't forget to soak the bamboo skewers!

text:
I made a few changes -- I used cilantro instead of basil in the marinade (I didn't have basil) and balsamic vinegar instead of wine vinegar.  I then later added the marinade to a can of diced tomatoes (roasted garlic) and the rest of the tomato sauce left over from the marinade and sauted the shrimp.  I served it over angel hair pasta. Really good.  I'm sure it's great the orginal way too.  I just felt like having a sauce to serve with it.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I chose this to serve to guests at a dinner party - without a test run - because of all the terrific ratings it received.  I was not disappointed.  I marinated the shrimp for about five hours in the fridge and then grilled them and served them on salads.  The flavor was outstanding - folks were fighting for the last few.  About a week later, I marinated another batch over night and then made an extra serving of the marinade. I prepared a pot of linguine and grilled the shrimp - then, just before serving, I added the second batch of marinade to the linguine and heated it on the stove top. My husband tells me that this is probably his all-time favorite dish.  Incredible flavor.  The fresh basil is really the key to this recipe, so don't use dried spices - or you'll be disappointed.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I must rave about this recipe! It was delicious, but I did improvise a little. I used Spicy Hot V8 juice instead of tomato sauce and white wine vinegar instead of red wine vinegar. While the shrimp was marinating I boiled some fettuccine and chopped fresh aspargus spears into 1/2 inch pieces. Instead of discarding the marinade I put it into a large skillet, brought it to a boil, and added the asparagus. I cooked the asparagus until it was bright green and removed it from the stove. I added the cooked fettuccine to the skillet right before I put the shrimp skewers onto the grill. As the shrimp were cooking I mixed the fettuccine mixture over high heat. When the shrimp were done I removed them from the skewers and served them on top of the fettuccine mixture and garnished it with shredded asiago cheese. Everyone in my family loved, loved, loved it! It was sooo good I'm thinking about serving it the next time we have guests.

Without a doubt the best shrimp marinade.  I forgot the garlic and it was still outstanding.  I marinated for 2 hours.    If you want the full flavor of any marinated shrimp recipe DO NOT use pre-cooked shrimp, it won't soak up the flavor nearly as well as uncooked.

text:
This recipe is awesome.  I prefer to thread the shrimp on skewers then marinade it.  The marinade actually stays on better this way.  If doing it this way, you need to double the recipe for the marinade.  I also increase the Cayan pepper in this recipe.  For a double recipe I use 3/4 teaspoons Cayan pepper.

Wow, this was incredible. I hate when people rate a recipe after making changes but thats what I am about to do. I did not have tomato sauce so I used half ketchup and half cocktail sauce and instead of red wine vinegar I used 1 T. of white wine vinegar and 1 T. of balsamic vinegar. This was AMAZING! I kept all the ingredients the same, but I adjusted the amounts according to my taste. I served the shrimp over a salad and made extra marinade to use as salad dressing. Yummy! text:
Delicious, easy and no extra shopping required!  We didn't have any fresh basil, so I substituted for dried basil.  Other than that, we mixed up the ingredients in a 9 x 13 Pyrex pan, skewered the shrimp, basted each skewer, put some cling wrap over the pan, popped it in the fridge for 4 hours, then grilled.  It was outstanding!  Plus, only one pan to clean up.  Thank you for a new family favorite!

This marinade was delicious! 

I used double the marinade for about 2 pounds of shrimp just because of reading all the reviews that said it wasn't very strong-tasting. That worked well because I boiled down the extra marinade and we brushed it on the shrimp as they grilled. 

The weird mix of ingredients works very well together, I know it looks strange. 

But with 1,465 reviews (mostly positive), you know it's something you should try making. Right? So make it!

I've been making this recipe for two years now, and I never rated it!!  Shame on me.  These shrimp have been the star of many get-togethers at our home.  I remember making them for my daughter's first communion party, and everyone raved about them.  Tonight I served them with long-grain rice and grilled asparagus with parmesan cheese.  This is my go to recipe whenever I'm in the mood for shrimp.  I make it frequently when the basil in my garden is plentiful, as I hate spending $2.88 for a small bunch in the grocery store!!  My kids love this recipe too.  If you haven't tried this one yet, you must.  It's a keeper!

I have been making this for over a year and everyone thinks it is just fantastic!  I have tweaked it a little...I use ketchup instead of tomato sauce and I add 1/4 cup of sweet red chili sauce.  Also, make sure you use either fresh basil or the basil that comes in those squeeze tubes in the produce section!  I also found it easier to place the shrimp in grilling baskets then on skewers.

text:
I made a few changes to add more flavor!I used tomato paste and a little water to make a thicker marinade that would cling to the shrimp for better grilled flavor.  I also added a little sugar so the sauce would carmelize on the shrimp as it grilled.  I soaked wooden skewers in water for 30 min.  so they would not burn on the grill.  The shrimp turned out very nice flavored and we enjoyed them very much.

FLAVORFUL! I did use ketchup, as one reviewer did, I used balsamic vinegar instead, and used 1 t dried Italian seasoning instead (only because I was missing the ingredients the recipe called for). TASTY! Thanks for the great starter recipe!!

text:
ok, like this really needed another large thumbs up. that being said..it is what it is...5 stars! i used fresh heirloom maters, elephant garlic, shallots and variaged basil. added a pinch of salt and honey. it marinated @ 10 hours. i pan fried this until shrimp turned pink. maybe 20 miuntes started from a large cold pan, mh. raining like crazy outside, no grilling. i used large shrimp. an excellent recipe that can beadapted to personal  tastes as long as you follow the the sweet/heat diameters.  i used an immersion blender in a short -sided glass bowl...don't use a short-sided bowl, believe me   :)

text:
I followed the basics in the recipe, but added a small finely diced serano pepper (sans seeds), 2tbsp finely diced red onion, and 1/2 tsp cumin.  I used a basil, oregano, and garlic tomato sauce and marinated everything for about 15 minutes refrigerated and 5 on the counter top.  I decided to cook this in a pot because I wanted to use the sauce.  Served over rice.  BF LOVED it, would give this 5 stars because it reminded him of ettouffe, expect with a little kick.  I'll save for when it gets colder and keep my changes as is.

These were awesome! I didn't have much time to prep before grilling - maybe 30 or 45 minutes. I used what I had on hand, meaning I subbed ketchup, and I used a few pinches of a spicy blend of herbs, plus about a 1/2 cup beer for good measure. Covered it all and let it marinate in the fridge for 20 or 30 minutes. Skewered and grilled following the directions and they knocked everyones socks off. This is my new favorite!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this dish on a whim just to try cooking shrimp, and boy was it great! I didn't have red wine vinegar, so instead used apple cider vinegar, which was a fine substitution. I let the shrimp marinade for about 2 hours, turning them in the refrigerator just to make sure all of them were getting coated and soaking in the flavor. I (unfortunately) had forgotten to buy fresh basil at the store and had to use dry basil. I was surprised that it still yielded a scrumptious marinade, although next time i will try the basil fresh instead of dried. I used a little sandwich grill inside and did not need to oil the grill because it was non stick. Make sure to watch them as they cook fast!

I really liked this as a marinade for grilled shrimp but I REALLY loved this recipe as an actual dressing for a cold shrimp salad.  I had leftover shrimp from the night before and I tossed the shrimp with fresh tomato, cucumber and the leftover marinade (do not use any leftover marinade that the raw shrimp touched).  A pinch of finishing salt....delicious!  I will be using this recipe in the future both as a dressing and a marinade!

text:
Made this exactly as the original recipe suggested--but substituted ketchup for the tomato sauce and 1 1 and 1/2 tablespoons dried basil for the two tablespoons of fresh basil.  I didn't even marinate at all, just put the shrimp, with marinade on the stovetop griddle and cooked for about 4 minutes first side, 3 minutes second side.  The marinade was AMAZING!  I have done this in saute pot before too and the sauce was so good it could have easily been used as a soup base or pasta sauce.  My boyfriend said "Wow" (nodding his head) "Remember this one!"  It wasn't too flavorful, but he liked how it didn't mask the shrimp flavor.

I served this with Italian Kale.

Finally, a recipe I had to rate!  At first bite, my husband and I looked at each other in happy amazement. The marinade thoroughly and deliciously flavored the shrimp (I marinated them for about 2 hours) and the hickory charcoal just added to it.  I made 12 large shrimp (1 lb.), cut the oil to 2 T. and used dried basil.  Took a chance and used the full 1/4 tsp. cayenne - perfect!  I would make at least half again the amount of marinade for 2 lbs. of shrimp.  Thanks for a most delicious recipe, Blondieperez!  I'm going to try the marinade on chicken breasts.

userID:
378929
Display Name:
luv2cook
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
9
favoritesCount:
190
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614262.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is awesome as a shrimp appetizer! For the tomato sauce, I substituted Taquera salsa, a tomatillo and Chile de Arbol sauce that I found at Trader Joes. Since this is very spicy salsa, I omitted the cayenne pepper. I also used cilantro instead of basil to better blend with the flavor of the salsa. I would recommend marinating the shrimp for a full hour to allow all of these wonderful flavors to be thoroughly absorbed prior to grilling. You can cook the shrimp on an indoor grill pan, which eliminates the need for the skewers; just flip them over with a pair of tongs. I left the tails on the shrimp, which makes for a fun finger food!

text:
I'm not a huge fan of shrimp, but since we went shrimping this year and have a freezer full I had to figure out something.  I get 99% of my recipes from this site and have yet to rate a recipe until this one.  This recipe is super amazing! Even though I had red wine vinegar on hand I used balsamic instead, ketchup instead of tomato sauce and dried basil. I soaked for a couple of hours and threw on BBQ.  I don't think I will try any other shrimp recipes....this one is a WINNER!  I did add twice the amount of cayenne since I am a spicy junkie :)

I always use extra virgin olive oil (more robust flavor).  Recently, I didn't have any tomato sauce, so I used chili sauce as another reviewer suggested.  Even better! text:
Wished I took a picture before I devoured the dish! Followed recipe with some additions. Used about 20 frozen, tail-on, shrimp. Sauce additions: 1 cup of Red Pack diced tomatoes seasoned with garlic and basil (in place of tomato sauce), dash of red pepper flakes, 1/4 cup sweet chili sauce (buy in Asian markets), extra minced garlic and basil to own liking. Marinated in sauce for 30 mins in fridge. Grilled on grill pan on stove top, lightly greased pan with olive oil. Cooked and removed shrimp as directed. Brought marinade to boil, adding 1/4 cup of chopped parsley. Served over pasta w/ organic vodka sauce (Trader Joe's). Smelled and tasted great!
Review:

text:
HUGE SUCCESS  its so nice when a recipe works as easily as this.  I followed the directions exactly, using JUMBO shrimp, which fit 3 to a bamboo skewer (be sure to soak the skewers in water first so they dont catch fire).  At $20 a pound, I prayed the shrimp would turn out okay but these are easily the BEST shrimp Ive ever eaten and Ive traveled the world! Absolutely, use only FRESH basil.  Toss everything into a large ziplock bag, squeeze out excess air; put in refrigerator.  I think I marinated it for a couple of hours. Really excellent  all of my guests gave this RAVE REVIEWS!  Was served at a birthday dinner with Crustless Spinach Quiche by Susan and Grilled Portobello Mushrooms by Michael (also from this site and 5*****).

text:
I was raised in FL eating shrimp all my life, but I have to say this is the very best shrimp recipe I've ever had. I almost passed it by because the tomato sauce sounded so odd in the marinade.  Don't skip it though - it's great. Using fresh ingredients is key, esp. the shrimp, garlic and basil. I double the marinade and soak all day or overnight for best flavor. Don't throw that amazing sauce away! Baste liberally during grilling to keep shrimp moist and extra flavorful. Serve with fresh garden salad and crisp white wine (recommended: Kim Crawford Sauvignon Blanc). We make at least once a week. Amazing.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is waaayy beyone AWESOME! It was just amazing! The shrimp came out perfect. They were moist and flavorful.  I made a couple of changes based on what I had in the house. I didn't have red wine vinegar so I used white wine vinegar. I also had a new product called "Garlic Juice" that I used instead of the fresh garlic. I also used dried basil since I didn't have fresh and used 2 tsps of that. I also doubled the recipe for 2lbs of shrimp because I love marinades and sauces and hate to not have enough. I made it the night before and I refrigerated it overnight. The next morning before I went to work I poured it over the shrimp. It marinated for about 9 hours and was still excellent with only about a quarter cup of marinade left over. For those that don't care for spicy, these were a teeny bit on the spicy side so you might want to cut back on the pepper a bit.  Personally, I love spicy and unless it makes my upper lip break out in a sweat, I don't consider it too hot! Wonderful recipe. I'll make this for the rest of my life! Thank you!

I used this marinade on mahi mahi fillets and then grilled them. It was delicious. I used balsamic vinegar in place of red wine vinegar and doubled the cayenne because we like spice. This dish will be served again soon.

userID:
10478002
Display Name:
bretthiggins
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
2
favoritesCount:
17
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/935269.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I will admit that I was skeptical about whether this recipe would live up to 5 stars...but I can't give it less.  I mostly stuck to the recipe, though I highly recommend tweaking it as I did- I used significantly more cayenne (I would suggest closer to a tbsp) and instead of the sauce I used fire roasted tomatoes and blended all the ingredients very briefly just to break down the tomatoes.  I spooned every bit of extra sauce on the shrimp while on the grill and you'd be a fool not to do the same.  Don't read this and think it's over-hyped, as this recipe is better than the reviews.  I also regret that I didn't make double the marinade and quickly boil some angel hair that could then be tossed with the extra sauce in a skillet to be topped with the shrimp...you too will regret it if you don't do the same.  I have never reviewed a recipe on here, but I went out of my way to come back to do so because I can't stop thinking about how good it was.  I will be making this again very soon.  FYI- I made this for my wife and a couple of friends and they were super impressed.  While the recipe is very simple to make, the flavor is so exceptional that it will have people thinking you are a professional chef.  I could babble even more...but they limit the number of characters you can use.  In summary, just make this and you will see that you'll go out of your way to review it as well...it's too superb not to.

region:

country:
None
text:
I thought this was one of the best grilled shrimp recipes I've ever had.  I made a few small modifications: used apple cider vinegar and red wine instead of the red wine vinegar (didn't have any), reduced the olive oil to 1/4 cup (and probably could've reduced a little more) added a little extra garlic and cayenne (we like things spicy!) and used dried basil since I didn't have fresh.  I grilled it on the Foreman since my husband wasn't home and he's the "grill man" and they turned out great.  I doubled the marinate and saved half to which I added a can of diced tomatoes and a little pasta sauce to pour over angel hair.  Delicious!

text:
I really wanted to find that 5 star marinade for shrimp but this just wasn't it.  With all the rave reviews I thought for sure this would end my search for the perfect grilled shrimp.  I made exactly as stated except I used dried basil as that is what I had.  I also added 1/2 TB of chili garlic sauce as others suggested.  It turned out a little too spicy for the kiddos.  I made twice the sauce and then extra for basting.  Turns out, there is just no time to baste so that was a waste.  Lesson learned.  Anyway, I might try these again if I end up with fresh basil around the house.

These are great. If you want a stronger flavor with the shrimp, marinate them for a longer period of time. I think 30 minutes to 1 hour is way too short. I always marinate for 2-3 hours and they turn out delicious every time! They are very versatile. You could serve them with rice or pasta or as an accompaniment to steak or fish. I have tried all the above combinations and love them all! Great recipe!

text:
I was skeptical because I don't like cocktail (tomato) sauce on shrimp. However, of all the shrimp recipes I've tried this is now one of my favorites. I've made it twice, once with some changes (lime juice instead of red wine vin., more garlic, used 1/2 tsp cajun spice instead of cayenne) and both times I used clamato intead of tomato sauce. Made as stated I rate this recipe 4 stars. It is very good. With my changes I gave it 5 - and so did my guests.

text:
Wow.  This dish was excellent.  We didn't have any canned tomatoes, so we used a combination of ketchup and chili sauce.  We didn't have any fresh basil so we used 2 teaspoons (not tablespoons) of dried basil.  Finally, we heated the grill and placed the shimp in a basket.  Will definitely make these again.  I think next time I will saute them on the stove top with a little olive oil and include a little portion of the marinade in the cooking process so that they are a little saucy.

text:
This was wonderful on a recent camping trip. The cayenne pepper adds just the right flavor without excess heat. Even my boyfriend who is super heat sensitive loved it. 

I used ketchup instead of tomato sauce and fresh basil from my garden. We used frozen shrimp and butterflied them before we put them in the marinade. Definitely keep some aside for basting if you decide to butterfly the shrimp instead of skewering them. 

I can't wait to try this on chicken and fish. At the end of the growing season I'll be mixing up a huge batch of this and freezing it for the winter!

text:
Everyone loved it, even my picky middle child!  I mistakenly used Sherry Cooking Wine (2 Tbsps) and then tried to fix it by adding 1 Tbsp White Wine Vinegar.  I only had dried McCormick basil leaves, so I used about 1/2 Tbsp. Also used leftover tomato sauce from a pasta dinner. The cayenne wasn't too spicy, although it was probably because I didn't allow it much time to marinate. I just let it sit for 5 minutes and started skewering.  Ran out of skewers, so I pulled out a tin pie pan and cooked the remaining shrimp in a little bit of marinade sauce on top of the grill. Delish!!

region:

country:
None
text:
These shrimp are amazing. I don't grill them since I don't have a grill. I cook them on the stovetop and serve over pasta or spaghetti squash. Since I don't discard the extra marinade, there is enough sauce to coat whatever you choose to serve it over.  I only made one change and that was reduce the amount of olive oil. I made it with  1/3 cup of olive oil the first time and it was too greasy for me. I reduced it to 3 Tablespoons which was perfect for how I serve it. I don't like a lot of oil in my food so this worked very well for me.

text:
As it was 30 degrees out and my indoor grill is on the fritz, I pan fried the shrimp in a bit of olive oil and then simmered them in the marinade.  I also made a few adjustments:  I had white wine vinegar instead of the red wine, and used diced tomatoes that were already flavored with balsamic vinegar, oregano and basil.  Overall, the result was stunning.   I made it a second time for company and it was a huge hit- this time, using the red wine vinegar.  It didn't make a difference in the taste.  Very easy - fantastic!

Since I didn't want to open a whole can of tomato sauce for just 1/4 cup, I did as others suggested and used ketchup instead.  It would have been fine if I had also remembered to leave out the salt when using ketchup!  It was too salty, but that was my fault.  Next time I plan on trying cocktail sauce instead of ketchup.  The olive oil makes the spices stick to the shrimp.  They look very appetizing.

text:
FABULOUS --- WITH 3 LITTLE CHANGES --- Now the #1 recipe in my grilling book.  This recipe is fantastic ... The shrimp is so flavorful I could not believe it . I would suggest 3 little changes which I did when I made this.  1) Double up all of the ingredients in the marinade --- with the same 2 pounds of shrimp, 2) Cover all the shrimp in the marinade and let it sit for 24 hours in the refrigerator before grilling and 3) Serve it over a rice pilaf.

I was pleasantly surprised by this dish. I didn't expect much flavor from the mild ingredients. I made very few changes - I used white wine vinegar and I added about a half teaspoon of Old Bay. Thanks for a good, solid recipe.

This recipe came to my attention through the allrecipes RSS feeds.  I made it last night for dinner, using no salt added tomato sauce, only a dash of salt, and 2 teaspoons of dried basil in place of the fresh.  Both of us really enjoyed this recipe and I will consider using the marinade as a barbecue baste for other meats like chicken just to see how it turns out.  I marinated the shrimp for 45 minutes, stirring everything together every 15 minutes to keep things mixed.  I will also consider using cilantro in place of the basil and perhaps less olive oil.  I will make this again.  Outstanding!  Thank you, Rachel!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great recipe. I make it all the time. I change a few things:

1) I use a lot more fresh basil than the recipe calls for.Cut it up in tiny pieces.
2) Save the marinade. While the shrimp are on the grill, add the entire can of tomato sauce (little can) to the reserved marinade and bring to a boil on stovetop.
3) Cook linguine noodles. After the marinade boils for a few minutes, add it to the cooked and drained pasta. 
4) Stir the grilled shrimp into the pasta. 

FABULOUS!!! Everyone always wants the recipe.

UPDATED: 7/9/17 I tried the recipe using the tomato sauce as the recipe stated and still find that I like subbing the tomato sauce with sweet thai chili sauce. photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674159.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I give this 4 stars only because I made the changes according to aussiemum1 but LOVED this dish.  I followed her ingredients but not exactly.  I only used 1 lb. of shrimp but made the recommended amount of marinade for 2 lbs. Instead of tomato sauce, I used a whole can of diced tomatoes, 3 cloves of garlic, 1/2 tsp of dried basil (no fresh on  hand), 1/4 cup sweet chili sauce, 1 Tbsp of red wine vinegar, 1/4 cup oil and pulsed all in a mini-processor.  I reserved about 3/4 cup of the marinade and heated that on the stove for dipping.  My husband and all three of my 3.5 year-olds loved it.  The kids ate more than me and my husband.  Next time, I'll make the 2 lbs and double the marinade as they loved the sauce for dipping.

text:
This is one of the best recipes I have tried from here, it was simple to put together, marinated the shrimp for over an hour.  Followed directions to the tee and the shrimp came our perfectly.  Everyone in the family enjoyed them, will definitely make this recipe again.  Next time will add more cayenne but seriously the grilled shrimp were just delicious!  I used large, meaty shrimp.  The shrimp is good hot or cold and does not really need a cocktail sauce as the shrimp is well seasoned.  Great recipe!

text:
Supremely Good! My wife isn't a fan of grilled shrimp and after she finished eating hers, ate half of mine as well!

I didn't have any tomato sauce on hand, so like others, I used ketchup instead.  Because ketchup has vinegar and salt in addition to tomatoes, I didn't use anymore salt and reduced the vinegar by a bit.  You could easily triple or quadruple the cayenne pepper if you like a bit of kick.

Best new recipe I've tried in a long time - thanks!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made this recipe for bbq with numerous people.  It is very easy especially since my store puts the shrimp on the sticks ahead of time for me.  I make the marinade and multiply it by5.  I put all shrimp skewers in a disposable aluminum tin, poor the marinade over and use as needed.  They cook extremely fast, easy to eat right off the sticks and all the kids will eat them too!  It is a huge hit in my house for dinner or large parties.  I highly recommend.  Fresh and light, common ingredients that you would have in the house (I have used dry basil before when I didn't have fresh) and it's always delicious.

Delicious! My guests loved it, too - I even heard a couple of "mmm's" after tasting it which is always nice  for the host to hear : )   Some changes: Added another 1 - 2 cloves of minced garlic, used ketchup in place of the tomato sauce and substituted freshly ground black pepper for the cayenne.  I loved how the marinade was thick and so it clung to the shrimp nicely in preparation for the grill.  I would definitely make this again!

text:
VERY good and simple!  Followed recipie exactly except I used dried basil.  (would have used fresh if I had it).  I used 1/2 of an 8oz can of tomato sauce for this recipe.  I took  the other 1/2 and added some garlic salt, dried basil & ground pepper and poured over sliced zucchini & onions tossed w/ olive oil-- threw that mixture into tented foil and grilled w/ the shrimp.  Served all over rice.  Delish w/ no complaints from the picky children.

text:
Really enjoyed this!  I looked at a few different recipes for grilled shrimp but I chose this one because of one of the other reviewers.  I always trust anything Naples 34102 rates a 5 star.  She recommended following the recipe exactly and that's what I did.  It worked wonderfully and made a BIG splash at the next door neighbors cookout.  Because we are right next door I was able to wait until the very last minute to put the shrimp on the grill and have them ready when all the other guests were ready to begin eating.  And such Ooohs and Ahhhs they caused!  Such a simple and wonderful recipe!  And in the unlikely event that there may be leftovers-well, these shrimp are even good served at room temp.  Don't know about serving them cold, they didn't last long enough!

text:
I was disappointed in this recipe for all the high ratings it received.  I followed the directions exactly but the marinade lacked flavor.  I think tomato sauce is a strange ingredient in a marinade for grilled shrimp.  The receipe calls for medium heat and 2-3 minutes per side or until opaque.  I used a gas grill maintained about 400 but it was not hot enough and cook time was more like 10 minutes total until they were opaque.  Taste was lacking for my husband and me and they still didn't looked cooked.  I would not make this again and was glad I had not made it for company. Meself in Lakeland

text:
This is a new family favorite. Made it last night and everyone raved about these shrimp. My daughter's friend who joined us for dinner asked if I would "PLEASE give the recipe to my mother"! The only changes I made was substituting 2 tablespoons of Trader Joe's Sweet Chili Sauce for the cayenne as I was concerned about it being too spicy for the kids, and I marinated it for about 2 hours, but otherwise I stuck to the recipe as it was written, and the flavor was outstanding!  I used Trader Joes Wild Blue Colossal Shrimp, fresh picked basil from our yard, and it is a dish I cannot wait to make for guests. Thanks so much for this wonderful recipe!

Awesome and quick!  I always triple the ingredients and add alot more garlic.  I often do not have fresh ginger when I prepare this, but it tastes just fine without.
I have used this with chicken too.
Tip for using with chicken, cook the chicken first or the sauce has a tendancy to stick to the pan.
If you need to leave on the stove longer than anticipated you can easily add more water to the pan.

text:
Excellent and SO easy! I took the advice of another reviewer and added 1/4 c. Chili Sauce-- DELICIOUS!  I highly recommend doing so!  I also subbed diced tomatoes for the tomato sauce, reduced the vinegar and oil and increased the basil and garlic.  What's more- I through everything in the skillet at the same time and served it over Quinoa that I made with some white wine, garlic and lemon.  Super good.  Oh, but if you do it this way and do NOT like spicy food (we do!) then I recommend reducing or eliminating the cayenne.  Enjoy!

text:
SO YUMMY!  I make this exactly as written, except for doubling the marinade (except olive oil) and adding 2 Tablespoons of Sweet Chili Sauce.    I marinade the shrimp for 90 minutes, grill on the Foreman Grill, boil the remaining sauce, and serve over white rice and broccoli with the extra sauce poured over the top, and cornbread on the side.  If you're a shrimp lover you will love this.  Thanks for adding!

text:
I have to believe this is definitely worthy of 5 stars, BUT, not the way I made it.  Based on another reviewer who subbed chili sauce for the tomato sauce, I did the same.  Well, this had excellent flavor, but by using the chili sauce, it came out too sweet.  I won't do that again.  I really liked the fact that this marinade is thicker than most and had nice "cling" to it.  These grilled up beautifully - had very nice color.  I'll be making this one again, but I'll use the tomato sauce next time!!  UPDATE: 9/4/10 - I made this again and used tomato sauce as directed by the recipe.  Wow, much better!!

Adding a little citrus, such as lemon or orange juice, along with twice the amount of Cayenne and red pepper flakes will kick this recipe up to where it should be.  Otherwise, while decent, it tastes like spicy ketchup.    Chardonnay?  Uh, no.  Try an ice-cold Rose or a chilled Zinfandel.  Seafood does not always = white wine!  Peace

text:
I made a delicious stir fry dish out of this shrimp and marinade! I doubled the marinade and then poured half of it over the shrimp in a glass dish to marinate. I cooked the shrimp in a skillet with sugar snap peas and sliced mushrooms in chili oil which gave it an extra kick. During the last minute of cooking, I poured in the rest of the marinade. When everything was heated, I mixed in some cooked brown rice. It was just the right amount of sauce. Yum.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677173.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My husband couldn't stop raving about(or eating!)these shrimp!  The kids even gobbled them up.  I doubled the recipe for the sauce and marinated them for about 8 hours.  I was out of fresh garlic and basil so I used garlic powder and dried basil, and they still were full of flavor.  Next time, I will use the fresh garlic and basil, but if you're in a pinch, the dried varieties work with great results.  I have a feeling hubby is going to be requesting this recipe a lot!  He labeled it "the best shrimp I have ever eaten."  Thanks for a great-tasting recipe, with a great "WOW" factor, that is also quick and easy to prepare.
UPDATE:  I made 6 lb. of these this weekend and took them to two different picnics.  They were the hit of the party with both crowds.  I swear I've NEVER received so many requests for a recipe before.  That makes this a 10 star recipe for sure!
Tip:  You can easily cut down on the oil a bit.  I didn't this time but did the time before.  Doesn't hurt the final results at all, just makes them a little healthier I suppose. I also think the marinade sticks to them a little better when you use less oil.

We absolutely love this recipe!!  However, we've stopped grilling it.  Instead we marinate cooked shrimp in the marinade (we substitute garlic-flavored tomato sauce).  Once the marination is complete, we put the entire batch into an oven-proof dish and add a stick of margarine, and bake for about 10-15 minutes.


oooh, yum yum!!  An easy shrimp-scampi like dish.  Easier than grilling and doesn't dry out at all./

WOW!  This shrimp is incredibly delicious! The whole family loved this, and I will definitely be making it again.

text:
I just made this and it was absolutely fantastic.  The only thing I did differently was to use 2t dried basil instead of 2T fresh.  I did let it marinade for the full hour.  Don't put the skewers on the grill and walk away.  Shrimp cooks so quickly.  I grabbed the middle shrimp with tongs and flipped them back and forth until opaque.  Nothing worse than overcooked shrimp...

The only ingredients I added to the shrimp were a drop of honey and a pinch of chopped ginger.  You can cut back on the olive oil and salt. A perfect meal to end the Memorial Day weekend.

text:
I took the advice from some other people and put this over pasta.  I halved the shrimp, thinking the marinade would serve as a sauce.  Which turned out wonderful, but not enough sauce!  So I would double the marinade.  I also used balsamic vinegar instead of red wine.  And I halved the cayenne pepper for fear of the taste with my sweet balsamic, which wasn't needed.  It wasn't too spicy, and could use the whole amount.  Next time I would add some chopped cooked tomatoes to the sauce. But overall this is a great (easy!)recipe, Thanks Rachel!!

text:
I beefed up the garlic and left the rest of the recipe the same.  (used dried seasonings). Marinated for a couple of hours, skewered and grilled over hickory.  this was paired with our Christmas prime rib and though we have trolled through different shrimp recipes each year all agree that this was the best and we will likely stick to this one going forward.  the tomato base and smoke pair this shrimp recipe with beef extremely well.  we had a dry cabernet with tobacco notes and would recommend a red over white with this fish recipe.  Thanks for this find!

text:
Have made it several times - it is a family favorite!  I basically follow the recipe, but usually substitute ketchup for tomato sauce, so as to not open a  full can for only a quarter cup.  I have used regular, spicy, and a combination of both types of ketchup.  Also used only white wine vinegar once because it was all I had on hand.  The shrimp still tasted yummy.  Have also used one tablespoon white wine vinegar and one tablespoon red wine vinegar and achieved wonderful results.  If we feel like kicking up the heat, I will add one-quarter teaspoon crushed red peppers.  No matter how we try it, we absolutely LOVE this recipe.  Thank you for sharing!

None
text:
This is the BEST shrimp marinade!  If you are in a hurry and don't want to have to let it sit for a half hour, or bother starting up the grill, these are great broiled.  I just mix the shrimp with the marinade, throw it on a foil covered cookie sheet (or broiler pan), and put it under the flame for a few minutes on each side.  I like to broil it until the shrimp gets slightly blackened on the edges.  My husband likes his spicy, so I add some Cajun's Choice creole seasoning or Tabasco sauce to his.  Yum!

text:
I sometimes look at the ingredients of recipes, and think really.  So that is when I look at the reviews, and thought almost 2k people cannot be wrong.  I had all ingredients on hand less the fresh basil. I used peel/eat shrimp, doubled the recipe to include 2 pieces of fish.  Mixed items together in the morning, and allowed it to marinate for the day.  I was nervous being as I was unfamiliar with the recipe.  Threw it on the grill, and dinner was done in about 10 minutes.  Served with a salad, and baked artichokes.  I must say this was the absolute BEST grilled shrimp recipe I have ever had.  My husband, and son raved about it as they were licking their fingers.  One change I made was throwing in 2 tablespoons of a spicy mango sauce I had on hand.  I intend on using this for the Fourth of July, and throwing in scallops, shrimp, and fish.

This recipe is hard to beat.I just made sure I used fresh garlic and fresh basil. I let them marinade for 6  hours plus after 3  hours I stirred the marinade to make sure all shrimp were adequately coated.One last thing you have to use a  grill to get maximum flavor. If you have a party ya better make a ton because hot off the grill because they will not last.One last thing  ( I promise )   Its always best to use fresh shrimp if at all possible. but you can use frozen uncooked shrimp if need be. The recipe is one of our favorites...Hope you enjoy them..

None
text:
This recipe is not the same as the one featured in the video - there was no red wine vinegar,basil or tomato sauce in the video - they used tomato paste and oregano.  Also black pepper and I believe red pepper flakes ...........hmmmmm something screwy here! Anyway - i did the recipe with the individual 2 Tbsp packets now available  of tomato paste, the red wine vinegar, seafood seasoning,  several dashes of cayenne, parsley. a splash only of olive oil and a good squeeze of fresh lemon and salt.  This turns out excellent and best yet if you leave the shells on  - it protects the shrimp during grilling in which you can skip the skewers if you get the bigger ones.  Definitely a favorite!

text:
Probably one of the simplest, tastiest shrimp recipes I've found in 20 years. One tip: If you find using skewers a pain, you can grill a whole whack of sumptuous shrimp by simply grilling them loose in a fish or veggie basket designed for grilling.Shortly after color changes they are done. Served on top of your family's favourite rice, everybody will be most satisfied. It's become a family favourite. Keep a bag of frozen shrimp on hand because this is quick and tasty and you'll be making it quite often once you try it.

text:
I tried this awhile back with recipe exactly as written.  We liked it and just returned to try again.  This time I did not have tomato sauce so I substituted with ketchup.  Couldn't find my skewers so I tossed the shrimp onto the George Foreman grill and cooked for a couple minutes.  Yum!  I like tomato ketchup better than the sauce - and now I don't have to worry about what to do with the leftover canned tomato sauce.  Excellent recipe either way, so easy and very tasty.  I think the fresh basil is a requirement - don't try to skip it.  The shrimp made a nice addition to the top of a spinach salad tonite.  We will use this again and again!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made it for a Memorial day cookout.  I have alot of guests who don't like hot/spicy food, so I made it as stated. Everyone loved these and were getting others to try them.  The guests were also trying to figure out what gave it that little heat.  I left them in the marinade overnight and used large already butterfield or deveined shrimp.  I soaked wooden skewers in water.  About two hours before the party, I put the shrimp on the skewers and let them continue to marinate in the sauce.  Didn't have to spend time preparing them after guests arrived.  When they were done, I slid the shrimp off onto small plates and put them out as appetizers.  They were a big hit.  Going to make them again for the 4th of July.

text:
I have made this recipe several times with a few variations.  Most importantly, fresh basil is a MUST.  Dried basil from the spice rack doesn't add any flavor to the shrimp.  Watch the amount of salt that you add, especially if the tomato sauce is salty.  The cayenne adds a subtle zing to the flavor.  If you like it more spicy, increase the cayenne.  Excellent recipe.  My family and friends love it!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this today for a poolside lunch with friends.  The only modifications were that I used 4 large cloves of garlic, and I grilled the shrimp on a grill pan over the stove and didn't bother to skewer them.  There were only 3 of us, but the 2lbs of shrimp were devoured in no time.  Too bad because I was really hoping for leftovers!  These would be great over pasta.  The 1/4tsp of cayenne gives nice flavor but not too much spice.  If you like things a bit spicier, I would increase the cayenne a bit. Overall, this is a terrific, easy recipe that is much better than many of the other grilled shrimp recipes I've tried.  I WILL be making this again!

i joined allrecipes just to review this recipe... it is SO GOOD!  i didn't have fresh basil or tomato sauce on hand but i did have trader joe's tomato and basil marinara sauce open so i used that and some ketchup to make up the 1/4c.  then i just added about a tsp or so dried basil... it was ooooooh sooooo good!  absolutely no need for cocktail sauce that would have totally ruined it!  i served it with salad and baked potatoes and everyone's plates were cleaned and smiles were on everyone's faces!  i don't think i will ever go with plain garlic butter shrimp again!

text:
A-M-A-Z-I-N-G! I love shrimp and always keep some in the freezer but I've never cooked them on the grill or marinated them (I know, its terrible). Mine sat in the fridge for a little over 2 hours (bad time planning on my part). I know everyone hates when people change recipes and then review them, but that's what makes this site great! I didn't have fresh basil or tomato sauce (I swear I was a mess today) so I added ketchup and dried basil. I also squirted a little lemon juice over my shrimp while they were marinating (what's shrimp without lemon juice?). Once my boyfriend put those things on the grill them smelled wonderful! Some of the best shrimp I've ever had...am planning on making these for a get together in a few weeks!!!!

userID:
2791511
Display Name:
MattyMix
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

5

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/61092.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made these shrimp a bunch of times now and they are consistently amazing, earning their five stars every time. You really can't go wrong with this recipe because it's very simple and quick, and since you only have to marinate for an hour you don't have to plan that far ahead to make something delicious.  I usually toss in extra cayenne pepper and I've also added a small amount of balsamic vinegar in place of some of the red wine vinegar before.  Since I personally like things to be fully submersed in a marinade, one warning is that this recipe doesn't make a lot of it.  I generally make a full batch of the marinade for one pound of shrimp (instead of two as listed), otherwise it ends up being a thin coating instead of something that is surrounding and covering every shrimp.  Of course this is a personal preference and the first time I made the recipe (using the full two pounds of shrimp) they still came out perfect.  You will not be disappointed by this recipe.  It lives up to the hype.

text:
Excellent with pasta.  I added 1/4 teaspoon of ground ginger for a little extra zip.  I also made a little extra to use as baste, spooning over the shrimp a little as they grilled.  I also reserved a couple of tablespoons to toss with the pasta.  The flavors are very complex so it is not obvious that the marinade is tomato-sauce based.

December '09: I marinated thin sliced fresh turkey breast & then grilled.  Excellent for those tired of roasted turkey.

text:
This was fantastic.  I made it for an end-of-summer cookout, and everyone loved it.  I followed the directions exactly, except subbing cilantro for the basil (a friend is allergic to basil, poor guy) and while the cilantro was good, I can imagine that the basil will make it fabulous (I love basil).  Next time I might try using ketchup for the tomato sauce; I personally thought that a little sweetness would have added something....or maybe a dash of Worcestershire or even some brown sugar.  The cayenne amount was just right for me, but my husband likes SPICY, so he could've taken more heat.  A dash of Tabasco, maybe?  The Chipotle Tabasco is really good, that might be worth a try sometime too.  Anyway, this one rated 5 stars the first time I tried it; I'm very excited to add my own personal touches and see how it comes out.  Thanks for sharing this wonderful recipe!

This is the best marinated shrimp I have ever had!!!  You should definitely try it!  I did cut the oil down to 1 tbsp to make it healthier.  I also didn't have fresh basil on hand, so I used dry basil.  It was wonderful!  Cutting down the oil does make this recipe spicier, which is fine by me, but some people don't do spicy.  If you don't do spicy and want to cut down the oil, then cut down the cayenne too.  I can't wait to try this marinade on chicken!

This is a great recipe that I have made several times. I use garlic & onion powder as well as some hot sauce to kick it up a bit more. Another variation is sauteing the shrimp in the sauce, make sure not to overcook then they get a rubbery texture. A very easy and delicious recipe, thanks!

text:
This is so yummy! The first time we made it I didn't feel like it had enough flavor, so now I let it marinate for at least 5 hours and the flavor is perfect. I also doubled the marinate part for my 2 lbs of jumbo shrimp. As the description says, don't let the cayenne pepper fool you. I can taste it, but as someone who's super sensitive to spicy foods, I found it to be just the right amount.

text:
My husband called home and announced that he was "in the mood for shrimp kabobs."  Still not entirely sure where the craving came from... but I turned to this site first.... and found that I had everything I needed for the recipe in the pantry.  It was easy to combine, no weird ingredients, and marinated quickly.  I put the shrimp on soaked bamboo skewers and alternated with lightly steamed zucchini, yellow squash, red grape tomatoes and red onion (both of those unsteamed)... and these were a hit.  They took a little longer to cook than the recipe stated... which was either the cold weather and/or my additional ingredients but I just covered the grill and that picked up the pace.  Excellent flavor.... and not spicy at all for us.  Thank you!!

text:
Overall the family rated this 4 stars, meaning, "it's really good- make it occasionally."  That works for me!  I used 1 lb with sauce doubled. Shrimp were partially thawed, so cooked unevenly- hence most were overdone as they continued heating while waiting for others to finish.  When in the bag marinating, it does NOT look like enough, but when cooked in covered skillet, it made enough to put over rice,  Did not like it left over as it was too "fishy."  YUM!

Display Name:
Travis

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674153.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this recipe last night for dinner and it was great! I did have to make a couple of changes to it due to lack of ingredients, but it worked out well. I substituted ketchup mixed with equal water in place of the tomato sauce and I substituted dried basil for the fresh basil. If using dry, be sure to use less than what the recipe calls for since it's usually stronger in flavor.

Something I hadn't planned, but I'm glad it did was that the ketchup imparted a sweet flavor which was awesome. The shrimp had a spicy / sweet taste and I loved it. I had also only bought 8 shrimp, so I had to make much less marinade. I put a little too much of the pepper, so it was spicier than it should have been. Still very good. 

I've used Allrecipes for a while now and I had to create an account just so I could review this recipe!

text:
This was a wonderful recipe! So easy and tasty, too. I made double the marinade, boiled it and set aside before adding the shrimp so I had something to dip the shrimp in after it was cooked. It took mere minutes to throw together and only a couple of minutes on the grill. I can't wait to make this as a quick appetizer for parties.

text:
YUMMY!!!  This was so quick and easy.  I made it exactly as the recipe states and it was wonderful.  I used jumbo pre-cooked shrimp instead of raw and it worked out just fine.  Since the shrimp were already cooked (no risk of cross contamination) I put the remainder of the marinade in a sauce pan and heated it to a boil to pour over my shrimp which I put over some rice with orzo (rice a roni garlic flavor...whole grain).  It was the perfect dish.  So, not only good, but healthy too.  Thanks for sharing this.  I'll make it over and over.

text:
This is an excellent recipe.  My whole family raved over it and even my small children asked for seconds.  The key really is to not over-cook the shrimp (which can be a little tricky on a grill.)  We grilled it on the lowest setting and removed the shrimp as soon as they turned pink.

This is definately a recipe you can make for company.  It is sure to impress!

Some of the best shrimp we've ever tasted!  I used pre-cooked shrimp, marinating 8 hours and grilling 1 minute per side.  Served this with Mid-Summer Italian Bread Salad, and the flavor of the shrimp didn't get lost at all (and that salad is powerful!).

text:
These were pretty good.  Like many others, first time grilling prawns (used instead of shrimp.)  Remember that if you are using wooden skewers, you need to soak them for about 20 minutes prior to using, so make sure to start soaking immediately after making your marinade.  I marinaded for 1.5 hours, and the taste really sank into the shrimp.  I cooked a minute or two more than called for.  Don't worry about them being too spicy- I can't handle spiciness at all, and these were fine- they were tinged with spiciness, lol.  Very quick and easy to make, and taste great.

text:
I made as written, my usual way to check a recipe, although Ive been known to wing it when I just have an idea or have to make do w/ items on hand, or just flying on my own idea. This recipe got great reviews and I had all on hand so I went w/ it. Just spicy enough...our lips were buzzing just like we like. I only used 12 large shrimp, plenty for the two of us. I had to surrender what I couldnt eat to hubby, often the case. Served with angel hair pasta, and boiled the marinade to make as sauce. YUM!! Needed more. Used more garlic (I always double the amount b/c we LOVE garlic! So I guess I did make an adjustment-we always double the garlic, no surprise there. No leftovers but will double amount of shrimp next time. I tasted the marinade once made and I was looking forward to how that would end up. Tasted a bit vinegary, but not once cooked, yummy! Thanks for the recipe, well be doing again!

I make this shrimp at least once a month.  I use 2 pounds of shrimp, but double the recipe for the marinade (except for the cayenne). So delicious.  Fresh basil is key!

text:
Excellent shrimp marinade. I followed the recipe, but used less than a pound of thawed shrimp with the shell on. I removed the shrimp from the pan when they were done cooking, mixed a small quantity of flour with a bit of water in small cup, and whisked it into the pan to thicken the sauce. The sauce was delicious over plain basmati rice.

text:
Made this last night along with lobster tail, king crab and scallops. the flavor was amazing. I did use the recipe almost exact except for the minced garlic. I didn't use the fresh garlic but instead used the seasoning it marinated the shrimp with a better flavor I also topped it off with fresh pepper and a dash of cayenne pepper. Marinated in the refrigerator for an hour and broiled on skewers at 550. I will keep this recipe for a long time.

This has become one of "go to" grilled shrimp recipes.  It's  flavorful, easy and made with pantry staples.  My mod's are to cut back to a couple of tablespoons on the oil, and ketchup instead of tomato sauce.   We up the basil, garlic and add crushed red pepper to give it a bit more kick. 4.28.18 Wouldnt change a thing in this recipe, IMO it was absolutely perfect!  I had my doubts about the tomato sauce in the marinade, but WOW, it just works folks.  Marinated large, beautiful Argentina Red Shrimp for an hour. text:
I know people hate when others do this but I'm doing it anyway; I followed other reviewers suggestions and did a can of diced tomatoes, 3 cloves minced garlic, lots of fresh basil, and 1/4 c of sweet chili sauce. I mixed those together in a food processor and tossed in a ziplock bag and marinated the shrimp in the fridge for 1-2 hours. Then I lined a grill rack with an aluminum foil open face packet and grilled the shrimp in its marinade for like 20-25 minutes.

It was ok. The flavor was sweet but I balanced it out by serving the shrimp and its marinade over idahoan red skin parmesan and garlic potatoes.

I can't decide if I'll make it again but no one was raving or anything.

Delicious!  I followed AussieMom1's advice and instead of tomato sauce used an entire (12 oz??) can of diced tomatoes with onions and garlic. Followed the rest of the recipe and pulsed the ingredients in my blender.  I marinated for about  2 hours. I put the shrimp on skewers and grilled on the top rack of my gas grill. I flipped every 2 or 3 minutes - I'd say it took about 10 minutes total.  I also cooked some of the leftover marinade for dipping sauce. My family of 4 devoured a 2 lb. bag of shrimp!

Absolutely Fantastic!!! I didn't have any tomato sauce on hand, so I used a can of "petite diced tomatoes with garlic & olive oil" in its place. text:
We tried the recipe as written and thought the shrimp were good.  The next time we made it, we used El Pato brand tomato sauce (spicy Mexican tomato sauce) instead of plain tomato sauce (& doubled the amount of tomato sauce).  We also added a Tablespoon of brown sugar.  We doubled the fresh basil, and when we skewered the shrimp before grilling, we sprinkled with Creole seasoning.  Even with all of the added spice, the shrimp are still not super spicy.  The young and old gobbled them up.  This is now our go-to marinade for grilled shrimp.

text:
I love cooking and I pride myself on the fact that I have ruined certain meals at restaurants for some of my family members. For example, my wife won't order lasagna at restaurants anymore and my wife and daughter won't order baby back ribs at restaurants anymore, because mine "are better" (their words, not mine). Many of my recipes have started out as someone else's recipe that I tweeked and/or perfected over time. However, this may be the first recipe I have ever used that I followed to the letter and I would not change a thing. I made this shrimp recipe with sides of herb & butter rice and grilled asparagus and the meal was restaurant quality. Again, I wouldn't change a thing and I definitely plan to make this again.

As with most of us, I had to make a couple of changes. The main one was that I added Cajun seasoning, and chili powder to the marinade.  It made for wonderful shrimp tacos the first time, then was a great accompaniment to grilled, blackened chicken thighs over brown rice!  I'll use this regularly throughout the summer! Thanks.

text:
Delish! I used balsamic vinegar in place of the red wine vinegar and it still turned out great. Do not use frozen shrimp unless it's all you can find, raw shrimp soaks in more marinade. Frozen works but it tastes about half as good. You can also use foil wraps in place of skewers, this way flipping is not required.

This recipe is simple and flavorful! I followed the recipe just as it's given and marinated the shrimp for about an hour and a half before grilling. I only had one pound of shrimp on hand so I used those with the full marinade recipe and used the leftover marinade to baste the shrimp while they were cooking. The next time I make them I may add some lemon juice for a little more tartness, but they're pretty darn good just the way the recipe calls for! This is definitely going in my dinner rotation. city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great shrimp recipe!!! I have made it many times. It is best to use the biggest shrimp you can afford. I have made minor adjustments over the years. I like things spicy so I add a little extra cayenne and a few squirts of Sriracha. if you don't like spicy make it exactly as the recipe is written. It is mild yet full of flavor. 
It is very important to use fresh basil. I tried dried once it was way off. If you don't have fresh basil, skip the dish. large shrimp are expensive so do it right. You will be so happy you did.

text:
loved this!!   I only had tomato paste which worked perfectly.  The paste was thinned out with the oil and vinegar and stuck to the shrimp easily.  I used dried basil and pan fried on top of the stove for a few minutes  until slightly pink.  I served it on angel hair pasta which i used the remainder of the sauce to coat the pasta.  Excellent!  The added spice from the cayenne made this a delightful dish.  I cant say enough about the great flavor in this dish.  I think the tomato paste i had on hand made all the difference for this dish.

October Lady

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674162.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Similar to other garlic shrimp recipes I've tried.  Tasty though.   Ingredient ratio was excellent.  Spice level was great. Very quick and easy.  Followed directions with two exceptions: Not  having  fresh basil on hand,  I substituted 2 tsp. dried basil, which I crushed before adding to the marinade.  Having an opened can of crushed tomatoes on hand, I substituted 1/4 cup of these for the tomato sauce.  I don't think either substitution drastically affected the taste.  I think I will make this recipe again.  I will try  substituting  chili sauce, just for a  taste comparison. I used large frozen  shrimp .  Next time  I will use  extra large or jumbo shrimp.  I think the large shrimp shrank too much while grilling. I used my indoor Jen-Air kitchen grill with excellent results.  I marinaded the shrimp for 1 hr.  Although the penetration of the marinade into the shrimp was good, I think I will lengthen the time the shrimp stays in the marinade an extra 30 mins. to 60 mins., just for some extra  flavor.

Thanks BlondiePerez for  posting this recipe.  It was fun to make and tasty to eat.

text:
I've made this several times over the last few weeks because it was quite a hit in our house! I have learned a few things about the recipe. 1. Fresh basil rather than dried really does make a tremendous difference to me. I couldn't find fresh basil at my local store (crazy, I know!), so I substituted dried once and it wasn't as good. Also, I use chili sauce instead of tomato sauce and balsamic vinegar rather than red wine vinegar, and it turns out just as amazing. I let the shrimp marinate all day or overnight whenever possible. This is so easy and so delicious!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I looked at AUSSIEMOM1 review and took it from there. Disclaimer: I didn't measure anything so this is all guessing. I added more basil (about 3-4 tblspns), 3 tblspns Sambal  Oelek, 1 1/2 tblspns of cayenne powder,  and 3 Thai peppers open and crushed to release the oils and the same amount of oil. I also omitted adding salt because the tomato sauce I have had plenty of sodium. Clearly,  only use this recipe if you like some heat. It doesn't come off super spicy but the heat builds as you eat. Again,  only try this recipe if you like spicy.

None
text:
Wow, excellent  recipe. When using 2 lbs jumbo shrimp, combined 14.5 oz petite diced tomatoes, 6 lg cloves garlic, 2 TBL each olive oil, dried basil, 4 TBL red wine vinegar and 1/2 tsp cayenne. Then used immersion blender to combine and marinated for 5 hours. Can't stop thinking about how good this was! Update: sauteed unmarinated shrimp on stovetop in 2 TBL butter and used heated marinade as sauce over shrimp and angel hair. Decreased cayenne to 1/4 tsp and used frsh basil. Yum.

text:
These were fantastic. I marinated them for 2 - 3 hours in a zip lock bag in the fridge,  mixing them every time I open the refrigerator.  I used a rounded  tsp. of cayenne  pepper and they had just the right zip. I forgot to add vinegar. The flavor was great. The secret is not to over grill the shrimp. Only 2 minutes on each side over medium heat. Be sure to dry the shrimp before putting them in the marinade.

text:
Love this recipe!! I doubled the marinade, but kept the amount of olive oil at 1/3 cup based on other reviews saying it was too heavy on the oil. Marinated for an hour and grilled outside in a grill pan instead of using skewers. Served over rice and my husband and extremely picky sons gobbled them up. Not one shrimp of two pounds left. Will make again with more marinade so I can reserve some to pour over rice. Thank you for sharing the recipe!

Fantastic. I tried the marinade for chicken breast pieces as well, since one of my daughters doesn't eat seafood. It was excellent on the chicken too. city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I followed this recipe almost to a T.  I accidentally used 1/3 cup too much tomato sauce and it didn't matter.  They were outstanding.  .  I always wanted to learn how to make something like this and let me tell you, it was a hit.  I bought 4 pounds of shrimp and had this for our Super Bowl party.  I made jasmine white rice seasoned with adobo including pepper.   You must soak the bamboo sticks in warm water for at least an hour so they don' burn up on the grill.  

They went so fast and everybody kept coming over to me expressing how flavorful they were.  My wife invited friends over the next day and demanded I make a fresh new batch.  

Thank you so much for this simple recipe which I for sure will use at every single tailgate party.

text:
This is the Williams-Sonoma recipe from the Grilling cookbook, I've been making it for at least 10 years now.  It is by far the best grilled shrimp around.  I usually cut the cayenne pepper by half and add some lemon juice to thin it a little.  Then I use the left over marinade to baste the shrimp after I turn them them on the grill.  These are really good either hot or cold.

I made this as written with the exception of a little more garlic and I used fresh Thai basil. Then I marinated a couple pounds of Argentine Pink Shrimp tails for a few hours in it. I can't say for certain that this is the perfect recipe for Argentine Pink Shrimp but, my wife and I agree that this was the best shrimp we've ever eaten! IMPORTANT!: If you use Argentine Pink Shrimp, resist temptation and DON'T overcook!! I hope this helps. We really did enjoy this meal!!!!!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I tried this twice -once as is and once with catsup(small amount) and asian chili sauce(larger amount) instead of tomato sauce, cutting the hot sauce some and adding some cayenne. The recipe shown here gets about a 2; the modded recipe Is an easy 5. 

Sorry I don't know the exact amounts; I usually go by taste and feel rather than exact amounts. Works well if you don't stray too far.

Luckily for me, the modded recipe was done with guests, as the stock one would not have gotten rave responses.

Certainly the hot sauce you use can make a difference, but I suspected the amount of tomato sauce recommended was not a wise choice. I was worried about using catsup in it's place as I don't have a sweet tooth, but going light with it and adding asian chili sauce is amazing. I got the catsup idea from someone else, so you might want to find that review and compare.

text:
Trying to come up with something "different" for dinner, I came across this recipe and had all the ingredients except the skewer sticks. When I went to buy them I saw that they had ON SALE 12 oz packages of shrimp already skewered. That is MORE than enough for two of us. I halved the recipe, added a bit of Old Bay Seasoning and marinated the shrimp in its frozen state for about four hours, in my refrigerator, turning occasionally. It thawed slowly and grilled easily. We loved this SO Much I went back next day and bought two more packages of skewered shrimp for my freezer! My husband loves the idea of serving this on pasta so maybe next time I will try that.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I tried this last night and was thrilled with the result. I used jumbo frozen uncooked shrimp. I cooked them on skewers in a grill pan on top of the stove, which closely mimics an outdoor grill and is much easier. 

Instead of the tomato sauce, I used half cocktail sauce and half ketchup. I used less than a 1/4 cup of olive oil, 3 tbsp basil, and a generous dose of cayenne. I like things on the spicy side. My guest doesn't like things too spicy, but she said it was fine. I LOVE this recipe and it will become my new GO-TO for shrimp from now on. I'm eating it cold off the skewer as I write this and it's fabulous the day after too.

text:
Tweaked this recipe a little bit. Added one teaspoon of parsley and one teaspoon of Cholula hot sauce. Changed cayenne pepper from 1/4 teaspoon to 3 teaspoons or so. Added 1/2 teaspoon of black pepper, and lastly squeezed in one small lemon. Marinated for 1 hour. Used uncooked jumbo shrimp on charcoal grill. Family LOVED this recipe. Made about 7 or 8 skewers full. Tasty and quick recipe. Easy to get full on before dinner so watch how many you eat!

text:
This recipe was delicious. I knew I would be short on time, so I made the marinade the night before, put the shrimp in a Ziploc bag with the marinade when I got home from work and let it set for about a half hour. I would have grilled, but it has been pouring rain all day. I didn't use the skewers, but just poured the whole thing on the broiler pan, and broiled for just about 2 -3 minutes each side. I used chili sauce instead of tomato sauce and may have gone a little heavy on the cayenne, but it was still delicious. Thank you for this! We will definitely make it again.

text:
These were delicious! They took slightly longer to cook than suggested, but they were still tender and juicy and delectable. I also made Paula Deen's cheese grits and broccoli rabe with garlic and cannellini beans and they both went perfectly with the shrimp. The shrimp were flavorful on their own but I jazzed them up a bit by serving with a sprinkle of Emeril's Essence and a wedge of lemon.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I admit, shrimp has never been my favorite seafood so I don't have much to compare this to. I made this for someone else and they really liked it. I normally think of shrimp as being slightly rubbery in texture, but this recipe they came out more meaty. I really liked that. As it was cold, I threw them in the broiler. I avoided the skewers as all they do is burn in the oven. I lined a baking sheet with foil and sprayed it with PAM. I marinated 1 lb of uncooked shrimp and made 1/2 recipe. I almost forgot about them and they were in the broiler on high for 14 minutes. Although, they seemed cooked just fine. I will try this on the grill another time too, for my shrimp lover.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
These shrimp were fabulous!  I used RoTel original tomato sauce with zesty tomato and green chilies, because that's what I had and a little extra cayenne.  This didn't appear to read as though it would pair well with cocktail sauce, so I mixed 2T mayo, 2T sour cream, 1/8 tsp. cayenne pepper, 1/2 tsp. hot sauce and 1/4 tsp. salt.  It went well with them.  My husband likes to have something to dip his seafood into!!  I think this would also be good with a squirt of lime and has anyone substituted cilantro for the basil?

text:
I made this with a few of the suggestions from other reviewers.  1 can of diced tomatos, extra garlic and basil, 1/4 cup of sweet chili sauce, and a couple red pepper flakes (because I didn't have cayenne). All into the food processor to chop and mix together. Then I marinated the shrimp for about 3 hours, and it was fantastic.  Stuck them on some skewers and grilled them, YUM! I will definitely be making this recipe again!

The shrimp were good...not "oh, wow, these are the best shrimp I've ever put in my mouth" good, but tasty nonetheless.  I took the suggestion from another poster and only used 2 T. olive oil. This was very easy and very amazing!  I'm not the best cook, so I need recipes that are fool-proof.  This fit the bill.  I took the fish basket off the hot part of the grill half way thru and poured more marinade over the shrimp to make sure they would be juicy. text:
I'm rating this 5 stars to get your attention, because as written, I think the tomato sauce makes it a bit bland.  I was going to add Chili Sauce, as one reviewer suggested, but found that I had none on hand.  Hmm--what to use?  Well, I decided to use half ketchup and half Tiger Sauce, which you can buy in your grocery store near the hot sauces.  It's a delicious spicy/sweet sauce.  I marinated the shrimp on Saturday, and  grilled it on Monday.  Well, let me tell you, the flavor was out of this world.  I served it over "Orzo with Parmesan and Basil" from this site, and my husband and I are still talking today about what a wonderful meal we enjoyed last evening.  It truly was to die for and so delicious over the orzo, which I made exactly as the recipe is written.  Give it a try, because these shrimp truly were scrumptious!

text:
I enjoyed this recipe very much.  I actually had to prepare these two different ways: grilled and broiled.  I didn't have enough skewers soaking to accommodate all of the shrimp so I ended up broiling about 1/2 lb.  I have to admit, if you can grill these the taste is much different and much better than if you prepare them another way.  I doubled the entire recipe so I would have enough marinade to baste the shrimp while they were cooking.  I marinated them for about an hour and my husband grilled them for about 4 minutes per side.  Very nice.  I served with grilled veggie packets and grilled baked potatoes.

I really enjoyed this recipe. Had to modify slightly b/c of what I had on hand.  Used 1 teaspoon dried basil instead of fresh, heinz chilli sauce instead of tomato sauce, added a touch of onion and garlic salt and marinated for about an hour.  It was delicious even with my changes!  My hubby and his friend ate every one in no time.  I served with pasta salad and potato wedges on the patio.  Perfect meal to start off the grilling season!

text:
This is my favorite recipe ever!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! I really can't understand how some people said this was bland. The flavors blend perfectly and are better than any shrimp I've ever had at a restaurant. We make this every two weeks and I would never dream of changing anything about this recipe and that's amazing coming from me because I tweek almost every recipe I get! We serve this with Guy Fieri's Bloody Mary flank steak and his Bomb Bakers ( baked potatoes that have been brined before they're baked and served with horseradish cream sauce), and asparagus with a balsalmic reduction. This has been on our Sunday dinner menu twice a month for 2 years now.The cayenne gives just the right kick. I will eat them until they are gone-no matter how many I make. I wish I could give this recipe 10 stars! Simplicity at its best! Thank you!This is also on my birthday dinner menu!

text:
This is, indeed, an extremely good yet simple recipe.  It tastes absolutely great!  I fixed with white shrimp (41-50 count).  The recipe is so simple, one can add or subtract easily.  I fixed 2 servings (.6 pounds) (for one person) so cut the recipe by 1/3 and make sure there was enough marinade to cover the shrimp in a re-sealable plastic bag.  I did not change anything except I didnt have any tomato sauce so I used 2 teas of ketchup and 2 teas of medium salsa.  I marinated for about 4 hours.  I will have this again and make a change or two.

I sauteed the garlic and part of an onion in oil, then added a bit of roasted red pepper, salt, pepper, cayenne, basil, and red wine vinegar and then took the remainder of the open can of sauce, plus 1 more. text:
I found this to be good but not great.  I omitted the salt, and used leftover pizza sauce instead of opening a can for 2 Tbsp. of tomato sauce.  I also marinated overnight, since it seems to really punch up the flavor levels.  I liked it, and would make it again, but it's not my favorite marinated shrimp recipe.
